qas.question: What did the decision ultimately uphold?
What was the state allowed to continue to fund?

answers.text: transportation of students to religious schools

qas.question: What did both the majority and dissenting opinions reiterate?

answers.text: that the Constitution has erected a "wall between church and state"

qas.question: What was the disagreement between the Justices over whether funding breached what?
What did Justice Jackson argue there were no grounds upon which to support what?
What did the decision not uphold?

plausible_answers.text: transportation of students to religious schools

qas.question: What was the state not allowed to continue to fund?

plausible_answers.text: that the Constitution has erected a "wall between church and state"

qas.question: What did neither the majority and dissenting opinions reiterate?
What was the agreement between the Justices over whether funding breached what?
What did Justice Jackson agree there were no grounds upon which to support what?

context: While the decision (with four dissents) ultimately upheld the <a0_0><b5_0>state law<b5_0/><a0_0/> allowing the funding of <a1_0><b6_0>transportation of students to religious schools<b6_0/><a1_0/>, the majority opinion (by Justice Hugo Black) and the dissenting opinions (by Justice Wiley Blount Rutledge and Justice Robert H. Jackson) each explicitly stated <a2_0><b7_0>that the Constitution has erected a "wall between church and state"<b7_0/><a2_0/> or a "separation of Church from State": their disagreement was limited to whether this case of state funding of transportation to religious schools breached <a3_0>that wall<a3_0/>. Rutledge, on behalf of the four dissenting justices, took the position that the majority had indeed permitted a violation of <b8_0>the wall<b8_0/> of separation in this case: "Neither so high nor so impregnable today as yesterday is the wall raised between church and state by Virginia's great statute of religious freedom and the First Amendment, now made applicable to all the states by the Fourteenth." Writing separately, Justice Jackson argued that "[T]here are no good grounds upon which to support <a4_0>the <b9_0>present legislation<b9_0/><a4_0/>. In fact, the undertones of the opinion, advocating complete and uncompromising separation of Church from State, seem utterly discordant with its conclusion yielding support to their commingling in educational matters."
